title: NASA's Big Moon Rocket is Ready for Launch
summary: NASA has moved a huge rocket to the launch pad in Florida to prepare for a special mission to the Moon. This rocket, called the Space Launch System, is very tall and was carried slowly on a big machine over many hours. Four astronauts will ride on this rocket for the Artemis II mission, which will take them around the Moon but not land on it. This is exciting because it's the first time people will go to the Moon in over 50 years since the Apollo missions. The rocket will do some final tests, like a dress rehearsal, before it can launch as early as February. The astronauts watched the rocket move and are getting ready for their journey into space.

a special trip or job to do something important

questions.question: What is the name of the big rocket NASA moved?
Where did NASA move the rocket to?
How many astronauts will go on the Artemis II mission?
Will the Artemis II mission land on the Moon?
options: No, it will go around the Moon
questions.correct_answer: No, it will go around the Moon

questions.question: When was the last time people went to the Moon before this mission?
What will the rocket do before it launches?
options: Final tests and a dress rehearsal
questions.correct_answer: Final tests and a dress rehearsal

background_read: NASA is a space agency that sends rockets and astronauts to explore space. The Moon is Earth's closest neighbor in space, and people first landed there in 1969. The Artemis missions are new trips to the Moon to learn more and maybe build a base there someday. Rockets are big machines that use fuel to fly up into space, and astronauts are brave people who train for years to go on these missions.
Article_Structure: WHAT: Moving a big rocket to the launch pad for a Moon mission
WHERE: Cape Canaveral, Florida at the Kennedy Space Center
WHY: To prepare for the first crewed mission to the Moon in over 50 years

perspectives.description: Many people are excited because this mission brings humans back to the Moon after a long time, showing progress in science and adventure.
